msContents.summary: This substantial woodblock print in pothi format encompasses the Liberation Story of the Previous Lives of Padmasambhava (Tib. གུ་རུ་པ་དྨ་འབྱུང་གནས་ཀྱི་སྐྱེས་རབས་རྣམ་པར་ཐར་པ). As indicated by the usage of gter tsheg in place of she, this is a "treasure text" or gter ma. Folios 1v and 2r, printed in red ink (evocative of Beijing Kangyur), feature illustrations of Buddha Śākyamuni and Padmasambhava respectively. The title is printed in Tibetan and (presumably) in the esoteric Uḍḍiyāna/Ḍākinī script on 1v. The remaining folios are printed in black ink, except the last folio, which contains the illustration of four dharmapālas in red ink. Each side is marked with corresponding Tibetan and Chinese page numbers. Intriguingly, the letter ka ཀ is inscribed above the Tibetan page number, while the term xitang 西唐 is noted above the Chinese page number. Both ka ཀ and xitang 西唐 could represent the Tibetan and Chinese titles of the text, respectively. ཀ, an abbreviation of བཀའ་ཐང, literally means 'chronicles,' and it refers to the Legend of Padmasambhava. This is corroborated in folio 463v, where the full word བཀའ་ཐང is written. The term Tang 唐 is the Chinese transcription of ཐང, while xi 西 may serve as a broad geographical reference to the location of Tibet. Therefore, Xitang can be interpreted as 'Chronicle of the West.'

supportDesc.condition: The print remains in an excellent state of preservation, although the first two folios have sustained some visible edge damage, including what appears to be an oil stain.
